## PHYSICS

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 515, 88]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a coil made from resistance wire.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 96, 668, 163]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 203, 898, 223]]<|/det|>
The coil is placed in cooking oil of mass \(m\). The total length of the resistance wire in the oil is \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 912, 256]]<|/det|>
A potential difference \(V\) is applied to the coil. The temperature of the oil increases by \(\Delta \theta\) in time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 576, 287]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\Delta \theta\) is related to \(L\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 291, 576, 323]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{A t V^{2}}{L} = m K \Delta \theta + Z\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 329, 732, 348]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the wire, and \(K\) and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 702, 380]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(\Delta \theta\) and \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 625, 411]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 702, 442]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(K\) and \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 383, 473]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 393, 503]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 410, 532]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 348, 561]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 351, 591]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 602, 447, 619]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of white light entering a transparent rectangular block. A narrow beam of light enters the block at the midpoint of one of the shorter sides. The angle of incidence \(\theta\) is measured, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 128, 831, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 409, 591, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label> <label>(not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
The distance \(d\) between the corner of the block and the point where the beam of light touches the boundary of the block is measured.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 486, 546, 505]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 569, 536]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(d\) and \(\theta\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 540, 561, 574]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{B}{B + d^2} = \frac{\sin^2\theta}{n^2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 580, 363, 598]]<|/det|>
where \(B\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 609, 146, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 692, 631]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(d^2\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{\sin^2\theta}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 611, 660]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 873, 917, 892]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 904, 917, 923]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 920, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 79, 149, 98]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 541, 107]]<|/det|> Values of \(\theta , \frac{1}{\sin^2 \theta}\) and \(d\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 112, 541, 131]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 144, 850, 457]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 464, 581, 485]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(d^2 /\mathrm{cm}^2\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 480, 485, 501]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(d^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 483, 918, 501]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 144, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 511, 180, 530]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 508, 715, 540]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(d^2 /\mathrm{cm}^2\) against \(\frac{1}{\sin^2\theta}\). Include error bars for \(d^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 530]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 543, 180, 562]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 542, 920, 580]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 556, 920, 575]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 590, 180, 609]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 588, 920, 624]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 809, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
gradient = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 225, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 256, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(B\) and \(n\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 440, 920, 460]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 146, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 691, 856, 710]]<|/det|>
